title: Citi Launches Seventh Annual Microentrepreneurship Award in Guatemala
summary: Guatemala City - For the seventh consecutive year and as part of Citi's commitment to developing microenterprise, the Citi Foundation, with the support of the Network of Guatemalan Microfinance Institutions (REDIMIF), announced the launch of the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards, Guatemala 2012.
tag-1: Citi Launches Seventh Annual Microentrepreneurship Award in Guatemala
tag-2: Guatemala City – For the seventh consecutive year and as part of Citi's commitment to developing microenterprise, the Citi Foundation, with the support of the Network of Guatemalan Microfinance Institutions (REDIMIF), announced the launch of the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards, Guatemala 2012.
tag-3: Over the last four years, the awards have recognized more than 55 microentrepreneurs. More than 300 individuals and 64 microfinance institutions have participated. The goal of the Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards is to acknowledge the innovation and achievements of microentrepreneurs in Guatemala, while helping to improve the quality of life of their families and communities.
tag-4: Previous winners have represented a wide range of activities. In 2006, for example, the grand prize went to Encarnación Sales Hernández, an outstanding entrepreneur who produces coffee, cereal, powdered beverages and flour, all derived from soy. The winner in 2007 was José Isaac Baquiax, a young man who started a company offering Internet services as well as computer sales, equipment and accessories. The year after that, Gladis Esperanza Rodríguez took home the top honor for her company, which makes flour, crackers, whole grain bread, pastries, cakes, powdered beverages, muffins and flan from a type of local nut. The 2009 winner, Julio Gustavo Pérez Maldonado, started from scratch to found the San Julián nursery, a supplier of ornamental plants, fruit trees, cactuses and other plants. In 2010, the prize went to Ovidio Armando Bautista Fuentes, a marimba player who teaches young people the art of playing this traditional instrument to preserve Guatemala's cultural heritage. Finally, last year's winner was Julio Rolando Barrientos Monzón, who noticed a need for educational opportunities in his community and decided to find a way to help aspiring students who cannot afford to go to school. He founded the San Felipe School, which offers basic education as well as specialized courses in such fields as accounting and bilingual secretarial skills.
tag-5: "The Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards have proved to be a success, not only because of the number of people who participate but also because we have created awareness around the world of the important role of microenterprise in local economies. They also highlight the importance of microcredit in stimulating developing in Guatemala, as is the case of these awards," commented Bernardo Chacin, Citi Guatemala's General Manager.
tag-6: Candidates for the awards are nominated by microfinance institutions, which select their best clients according to the established eligibility requirements. A description of these requirements and application forms can be found at www.redimif.org. More than applications are expected this year from REDIMIF's network of affiliates.
tag-7: The seventh annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards will honor 11 microentrepreneurs in different categories. For the third consecutive year, female entrepreneurs will be recognized with a special "Women4Citi" award. Other categories will acknowledge micro businesses that demonstrate concern for natural resources and contribute to sustainable development.
tag-8: The Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards are a joint effort of the Citi Foundation and the Network of Guatemalan Microfinance Institutions (REDIMIF). REDIMIF currently has 15 affiliated microfinance institutions and serves more than 130,000 micro, small and medium enterprises around the country via 125 offices and branches. Its loan portfolio exceeds $75 million.

tag-11: In each category, prizes will be awarded for First Place (US$1,400), Second Place (US$1,100) and Third Place (US$850), tax free.
tag-12: A grand prize winner will be selected from among the three prize-winners in each category. The grand prize winner will take home US$3,250 tax free in recognition of his or her innovation and business trajectory.
tag-13: The 2012 awards will also honor microfinance institution whose innovative projects showcase the value of developing microfinance in Guatemala. The winner will receive US$10,000.
tag-14: All organizations with micro-financing programs are invited to participate. Applications will be accepted from June 6 through September 14, 2012 at REDIMIF, Avenida Reforma 10-00 zone 9, Condominio Reforma Building, 4th Floor, Office No. 4. Citi Guatemala volunteers will review the applications and a committee of judges, composed of microfinance experts, journalists and prominent Guatemalans, will select the winners. Finalists and winners in each category will be announced in late November 2012 at an awards ceremony in Guatemala City.
tag-15: For more information about the program, or if you would like to participate, please contact Daniel Ruiz at REDIMIF, 23613707 or 23613647, redimif@redimif.org and asistente@redimif.org – www.redimif.org.
tag-16: Citi Citi, the leading global bank, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.

tag-18: REDIMIF The Network of Guatemalan Microfinance Institutions (REDIMIF) is an association made up of associations and foundations that work in the microfinance sector. It represents its members and coordinates and channels resources and efforts to promote mutually beneficial projects. REDIMIF serves the nation through 17 affiliated institutions, which work with more than 158,000 micro and small enterprises at 118 offices and branches. More than half - 53.65% - of REDIMIF's loan portfolio is in rural areas and 66% of its lenders are women. For more information, please visit www.redimif.org and www.redcamif.org.
tag-19: The Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation is committed to the economic empowerment and financial inclusion of individuals and families, particularly those in need, in the communities where we work so that they can improve their standard of living. Globally, the Citi Foundation targets its strategic giving to priority focus areas: Microfinance, Enterprise Development, Youth Education and Livelihoods, and Financial Capability and Asset Building. The Citi Foundation works with its partners in Microfinance and Enterprise Development to support environmental programs and innovations. Additional information can be found at www.citifoundation.com.
